column1: Sault Ste. Marie ( SOO-seint-ma-REE) is a city on the St. Marys River in Ontario
column2: Canada
column3: close to the Canada–US border. It is the seat of the Algoma District and the third largest city in Northern Ontario
column4: after Sudbury and Thunder Bay.

column2: the indigenous Anishinaabe inhabitants of the area
column3: call this area Baawitigong
column4: meaning "place of the rapids." They used this as a regional meeting place during whitefish season in the St. Mary's Rapids. (The anglicized form of this name
column5: Bawating
column6: is used in institutional and geographic names in the area.)

column2: across the river
column3: is the United States and the Michigan city of the same name. These two communities were one city until a new treaty after the War of 1812 established the border between Canada and the United States in this area at the St. Mary's River. In the 21st century
column4: the two cities are joined by the International Bridge
column5: which connects Interstate 75 on the Michigan side
column6: and Huron Street (and former Ontario Secondary Highway 550B) on the Ontario side. Shipping traffic in the Great Lakes system bypasses the Saint Mary's Rapids via the American Soo Locks
column7: the world's busiest canal in terms of tonnage that passes through it
column8: while smaller recreational and tour boats use the Canadian Sault Ste. Marie Canal.

column1: French colonists referred to the rapids on the river as Les Saults de Ste. Marie and the village name was derived from that. The rapids and cascades of the St. Mary's River descend more than 6 m (20 ft) from the level of Lake Superior to the level of the lower lakes. Hundreds of years ago
column2: this slowed shipping traffic
column3: requiring an overland portage of boats and cargo from one lake to the other.  The entire name translates to "Saint Mary's Rapids" or "Saint Mary's Falls". The word sault is pronounced [so] in French
column4: and  in the English pronunciation of the city name. Residents of the city are called Saultites.Sault Ste. Marie is bordered to the east by the Rankin and Garden River First Nation reserves
column5: and to the west by Prince Township. To the north
column6: the city is bordered by an unincorporated portion of Algoma District
column7: which includes the local services boards of Aweres

column2: mostly of Ojibwe-speaking peoples
column3: existed here for more than 500 years. In the late 17th century
column4: French Jesuit missionaries established a mission at the First Nations village. This was followed by development of a fur trading post and larger settlement
column5: as traders
column6: trappers and Native Americans were attracted to the community. It was considered one community and part of Canada until after the War of 1812 and settlement of the border between Canada and the US at the Ste. Mary's River. At that time
column7: the US prohibited British traders from any longer operating in its territory
column8: and the areas separated by the river began to develop as two communities

column1: After the visit of Étienne Brûlé in 1623
column2: the French called it "Sault de Gaston" in honour of Gaston
column3: Duke of Orléans
column4: the brother of King Louis XIII of France. In 1668
column5: French Jesuit missionaries renamed it as Sault Sainte Marie
column6: and established a mission settlement (present-day Sault Ste. Marie
column7: Michigan) on the river's south bank.

column2: a fur trading post was established and the settlement expanded to include both sides of the river.  Sault Ste. Marie is one of the oldest French settlements in North America.  It was at the crossroads of the 5
column3: 000-kilometre (3
column4: 000-mile) fur trade route
column5: which stretched from Montreal to Sault Ste. Marie and to the North country above Lake Superior. A cosmopolitan
column6: mixed population of Europeans
column8: and Métis lived at the village spanning the river.The city name originates from Saults de Sainte-Marie
column10: a reference to the rapids of Saint Marys River. Etymologically
column11: the word sault comes from an archaic spelling of saut (from sauter)
column12: which translates most accurately in this usage to the English word cataract.  This in turn derives from the French word for "leap" or "jump" (similar to somersault). Citations dating back to 1600 use the sault spelling to mean a cataract
column13: waterfall or rapids. In modern French
column15: the words chutes or rapides are more usual. Sault survives almost exclusively in geographic names dating from the 17th century. (See also Long Sault
column21: three other place names where "sault" also carries this meaning.)

column1: This fluid environment changed during and after the War of 1812 between Britain and the United States. Trade dropped during the war and on July 20
column2: 1814 an American force destroyed the North West Company depot on the north shore of the St. Marys River. Since the Americans were unable to capture Fort Mackinac
column3: the British forces retained control of Sault Ste. Marie. As noted
column4: after the war with a new border defined
column5: the US closed its territory to British Canadian traders
column6: shutting off much interaction.

column2: the United States refused to give the steamer Chicona
column3: carrying Colonel Garnet Wolseley
column4: permission to pass through the locks at Sault Ste Marie. In order to control their own water passage
column5: the Canadians constructed the Sault Ste. Marie Canal
column6: which was completed in 1895.Sault Ste. Marie
column7: Ontario was incorporated as a town in 1887 and a city in 1912. The town gained brief international notoriety in 1911 in the trial of Angelina Napolitano
column8: the first person in Canada to use the battered woman defence for murder.During World War II
column9: and particularly after the US was attacked at Pearl Harbor in 1941
column10: government concern turned to protection of the locks and shipping channel at Sault Ste. Marie. A substantial military presence was established to protect the locks from a possible attack by Nazi German aircraft from the north. The recent development of long-range bombers increased fears of a sudden air raid.  Military strategists studied polar projection maps
column11: which indicated that the air distance from occupied Norway to the town was about the same as the distance from Norway to New York. That direct route of about 5
column13: 000 miles) is over terrain where there were few observers and long winter nights.

column1: A joint Canadian and US committee called the "Permanent Joint Board on Defence" drove the installation of anti-aircraft defence and associated units of the United States Army Air Forces and Royal Canadian Air Force to defend the locks.  An anti-aircraft training facility was established 100 km (60 mi) north of Sault Ste. Marie on the shores of Lake Superior.  Barrage balloons were installed
column2: and early warning radar bases were established at five locations in northern Ontario (Kapuskasing
column3: Cochrane
column4: Hearst
column5: Armstrong (Thunder Bay District)
column6: and Nakina) to watch for incoming aircraft. Military personnel were established to guard sensitive parts of the transportation infrastructure.  A little over one year later
column8: most of these facilities and defences were deemed excessive and removed
column9: save a reduced military base at Sault Ste. Marie.

column1: The first Algerine-class minesweeper in the Royal Canadian Navy was named HMCS Sault Ste. Marie (J334) after the city. It was laid down in 1942 and acted as a convoy in the Battle of the Atlantic.

column3: Sault Ste. Marie became a flashpoint in the Meech Lake Accord constitutional debate when council passed a resolution declaring English as the city's official language and the sole language for provision of municipal services. French speakers had already gained the use of French as an official language for government services. The city had a sizable French-speaking population and these residents objected strongly to the council's action. The Sault Ste. Marie language resolution was not the first of its kind in Ontario
column4: but the municipality was the largest to have passed such a resolution and the first to do so despite its sizable Franco-Ontarian population.

column1: Sault Ste. Marie has a humid continental climate (Köppen climate classification Dfb) with cold
column2: snowy winters and warm summers that are moderated to some extent by Lake Superior. Winters are cold but are milder than some inland places. Temperatures drop below −20 °C (−4 °F) 24 days per year. Summers are warm with a July high of 24.0 °C (75.2 °F) and temperatures above 30 °C (86 °F) occur 4 days per year. The average annual precipitation is 889 mm (35.0 in)
column3: which is fairly evenly distributed throughout the year; February is the driest month
column4: and the autumn months of September to November are the wettest months. The highest temperature ever recorded in Sault Ste. Marie was 37.2 °C (99.0 °F) on 3 July 1921
column5: while the record low was −41.1 °C (−42.0 °F) on 26 January 1927.

column1: The city developed considerable industry before and after World War II
column2: especially in steel-making. Algoma (formerly  Algoma Steel; Essar Steel Algoma) is the largest single employer
column3: with 3500 employees at the main plant and approximately 553 (440 unionized and 113 non-unionized) at an adjacent tube mill operated by Tenaris. During the 1940s
column4: the steel and chromium operations were of substantial importance to the war effort in Canada and the United States. Algoma Steel and the Chromium Mining and Smelting Corporation were key producers for transportation and military machines.

column1: The Huron Central Railway has been important into the 21st century to the operation of the steel operation
column2: despite extensive railway restructuring elsewhere. Genesee and Wyoming
column3: Inc.
column4: owner of the railway
column5: announced its intention to discontinue operations. It continued to operate under an agreement which terminated on August 15

column1: Sault Ste. Marie prospered during the 1960s and '70s
column2: but as imported steel began to compete with domestic production
column3: the local industry began to contract. Since the late 1980s
column4: Algoma has declared bankruptcy twice and laid off large numbers of workers
column5: adversely affecting the regional economy. Algoma was bailed out by the Ontario government with interest-free loans. The company had a swift turnaround in 2004 from its earlier financial troubles of the 1990s. China's increased demand for steel of the past decade has increased the price of steel. Denis Turcotte
column6: CEO
column7: was named "Canadian CEO of the year" in 2006 for his efforts. An offer to purchase ASI by the Essar Group (India) had been recommended by the ASI Board of Directors and was approved. The company was officially sold to the Essar Group in June 2007 for $1.6 billion.

column1: Forestry is also a major local industry. St. Mary's Paper has been closed and decommissioned
column2: although it was reopened in June 2007 and operated for a time under new ownership. Also related to wood products is Flakeboard Ltd.
column3: which employs over 110 people in the community. An adjacent melamine factory manufactures products with Flakeboard's materials. Examples are furniture and cupboards where a finish is added to the product. Together both of Flakeboard's factories employ about 150 people. The Huron Central Railway is important to these local industries as well.

column1: The business process outsourcing industry had three call centres in the city
column2: which together employed about 1500 people. The largest
column3: Sutherland Global Services
column4: closed in 2019 and Agero is closing in April 2020. Nucomm previously had a call centre here as well. The call centre industry became a major source of jobs and had contributed to the economic turnaround of the city in the late 1990s.

column1: Another large employer in the community is the Ontario Lottery and Gaming Corporation (OLG). The OLG has a corporate office located on the waterfront. It employs a total of about 900 people in Sault Ste. Marie between the corporate office and OLG Casino Sault Ste. Marie. The prize centre used to be administered in the city but this operation was moved back to Toronto (York Mills) in 2009. The OLG is still the fourth-largest employer
column2: after Algoma Steel
column3: Sault Area Hospital
column4: and the call centre industry.

column1: Sault Ste. Marie is one of only a few cities in Ontario where a municipal bylaw prevents stores from opening on December 26
column2: a Commonwealth holiday known as Boxing Day
column3: and the day after Christmas. Retail stores in Sault Ste. Marie begin their post-Christmas Boxing Day sales on December 27. A municipal referendum to determine whether voters favour allowing stores to open on Boxing Day was held concurrently with the 2010 municipal election. Voter turnout was not high enough to make the referendum legally binding
column4: but 60.77 per cent of voters opposed allowing stores to open on the holiday.

column1: The Sault Ste. Marie Solar Park (68 MW)
column2: co-generation plant (Brookfield Power)
column3: F. H. Clergue Hydroelectric Generating Station
column4: nearby Prince Township Wind Farm (189 MW) and several nearby hydroelectric dams
column5: form part of the city's push to develop alternative forms of energy and gain the title of 'Alternative Energy Capital of North America'. Two other wind farms are proposed for the area: the Goulais wind farm (25 MW) and the Bow Lake wind farm (58 MW)
column6: in partnership with the Batchewana First Nation of Ojibways to be built near Montreal River Harbour. Elementa Group has built a pilot waste-to-energy plant in Sault Ste. Marie
column7: and the local Public Utilities Commission collects methane gas from the city's landfill.

column1: Sault Ste. Marie is served by Highway 17
column2: designated as a segment of the Trans-Canada Highway in the region. The highway connects the city to Thunder Bay to the northwest and Sudbury to the east. The International Bridge connects downtown Sault Ste. Marie to Sault Ste. Marie
column3: Michigan
column4: becoming Interstate 75 on the American side. Interstate 75 continues south to Saginaw
column5: Flint
column6: and Detroit before crossing into Ohio

column1: The International Bridge also directs traffic from the American side of the border via Sault Ste. Marie's new transport route that runs from the bridge to Second Line. This new limited-access roadway
column2: known as "Carmen's Way" after the late MP Carmen Provenzano
column3: will make it much easier for transport trucks to reach main roads. The route of Carmen's Way has a wide grassy right-of-way on both sides of the roadway
column4: to facilitate future expansion of its lane capacity. Planning is underway to eventually connect Second Line East to the new four-lane section of Highway 17 that recently opened east of the city.

column1: The city plays an inherited role in marine transportation
column2: with the locks in Michigan being an integral component of the St. Lawrence Seaway. The city operates its own small-scale lock which is used by small boats and other pleasure craft in the summer. Also recently opened is a multi-modal terminal designed to take advantage of the Sault as a rail
column3: road
column4: and water transportation hub.

column1: Sault Ste. Marie is also served by Sault Ste. Marie Airport and Sault Transit Services. The city is no longer connected by passenger rail to any other major cities
column2: but is part of the Algoma Central Railway network
column3: which runs north from the city to the small town of Hearst. In 2006 the city's Member of Parliament
column4: Tony Martin
column5: called for passenger rail service to be reinstated between Sault Ste. Marie and Sudbury.In 2018
column6: Ontario Northland announced a major service expansion west of Sudbury
column7: which includes multiple stops in Sault Ste. Marie. Passengers may board buses headed toward Hearst
column9: or Manitoulin Island. ONTC currently has three stops in the city
column10: with the main stop being along Trunk Road on the east end
column11: and the other stops being at Sault College and the hospital.

column1: Christianity is the chief faith in the city
column2: with Roman Catholicism being the largest denomination.  This can be attributed to the large number of citizens with a traditional French and Italian Catholic heritage. After Catholicism and Protestantism
column3: those who identify as being non-religious make up almost one-quarter of residents.

column1: The Corporation of the City of Sault Ste. Marie is run by a city council of 10 councillors (representing five wards) and a mayor. The most recent municipal election was held on October 22
column3: and the mayoralty was won by incumbent Christian Provenzano
column4: who garnered 70.15% of the vote.

column1: The city is served by the Sault Ste. Marie federal electoral district and the Sault Ste. Marie provincial electoral district. The boundaries of these two districts are not identical; the provincial district encompasses the city alone
column2: while the federal district includes the neighbouring Garden River and Rankin reserves
column3: and extends northerly to the Montreal River. The city's current federal Member of Parliament is Terry Sheehan (Liberal)
column4: and its seat in the provincial legislature is Ross Romano (Conservative).

column1: Sault Ste. Marie has over 30 elementary schools.

The Sault Ste. Marie Greyhounds are the city's most recognized sports team having existed since the formation of the Northern Ontario Hockey Association in 1919.  The Hounds won national championships twice including the 1993 Memorial Cup and the 1924 Allan Cup. The Greyhounds play in the GFL Memorial Gardens
column2: a state-of-the-art downtown arena that replaced the Sault Memorial Gardens in 2006. The current Hounds have retired five jerseys since joining the Ontario Hockey League in 1972:  #1 John Vanbiesbrouck
column3: #4 Craig Hartsburg
column4: #10 Ron Francis
column5: #5 Adam Foote
column6: and #99 Wayne Gretzky.

column1: Sault Ste. Marie also had a team in hockey's first professional league. The Sault Ste. Marie Marlboros or 'Canadian Soo' team played in the International Professional Hockey League from 1904 to 1907.
Sault Ste. Marie hockey teams have boasted a number of Hockey Hall of Fame members
column2: including Sault natives or residents Phil Esposito
column3: Tony Esposito
column4: Ron Francis
column5: and Didier Pitre
column6: as well as Sault team members Gerry Cheevers

column1: National Hockey League All-Stars Joe Thornton & Jeff Carter played their entire OHL careers as members of the Greyhounds. Current NHL players from the Sault Ste. Marie area include New Jersey Devils centre Tyler Kennedy
column2: Buffalo Sabres centre Jordan Nolan
column3: St.Louis Blues centre Chris Thorburn and Vegas Golden Knights defense Colin Miller
